natural problem: What is the sum of all the positive two-digit integers where one of the digits is four times the other?
natural solution: The only such possible two-digit integers will be composed with either a 1 and a 4 or a 2 and an 8.
So, we simply want to compute $14+41+28+82$.
Adding the first two and the last two in pairs gives $55 + 110$, which is easily computed to be $\boxed{165}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 10"
and h1 : "n \<le> 99"
and h2 : "\<exists> a b. n = a*10 + b \<and> (a = 4*b \<or> b = 4*a)"
shows  "sum id {n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n \<le> 99 \<and> (\<exists> a b. n = a*10 + b \<and> (a = 4*b \<or> b = 4*a))} = 165"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all the positive two-digit integers where one of the digits is four times the other? The final Answer is 165
 ### Proof
 The only such possible two-digit integers will be composed with either a 1 and a 4 or a 2 and an 8.
 So, we simply want to compute $14+41+28+82$.
 Adding the first two and the last two in pairs gives $55 + 110$, which is easily computed to be $\boxed{165}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 10"
and h1 : "n \<le> 99"
and h2 : "\<exists> a b. n = a*10 + b \<and> (a = 4*b \<or> b = 4*a)"
shows  "sum id {n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n \<le> 99 \<and> (\<exists> a b. n = a*10 + b \<and> (a = 4*b \<or> b = 4*a))} = 165"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the sum of all two-digit numbers (from 10 to 99) such that the number is a multiple of 10 added to another number, and either the first number is four times the second number, or the second number is four times the first number. The sum of these numbers is 165.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "10 \<le> i \<and> i < 100"
and h1 : "10 \<le> j \<and> j < 100"
and h2 : "\<forall>i j. i = 4 * j \<or> j = 4 * i"
shows  "sum id {i,j} = 165"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all the positive two-digit integers where one of the digits is four times the other? The final Answer is 165
 ### Proof
 The only such possible two-digit integers will be composed with either a 1 and a 4 or a 2 and an 8.
 So, we simply want to compute $14+41+28+82$.
 Adding the first two and the last two in pairs gives $55 + 110$, which is easily computed to be $\boxed{165}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "10 \<le> i \<and> i < 100"
and h1 : "10 \<le> j \<and> j < 100"
and h2 : "\<forall>i j. i = 4 * j \<or> j = 4 * i"
shows  "sum id {i,j} = 165"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find two positive integers $i$ and $j$, both between $10$ and $100$, such that either $i$ is four times $j$ or $j$ is four times $i$. The sum of $i$ and $j$ is $165$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sum :: int
assumes h0 : "sum = (\<Sum>x\<in>{(10*a + b)| a b. a \<in> {1..9} & b \<in> {0..9} & (a = 4 * b | b = 4 * a)}. x)"
shows  "sum = 165"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all the positive two-digit integers where one of the digits is four times the other? The final Answer is 165
 ### Proof
 The only such possible two-digit integers will be composed with either a 1 and a 4 or a 2 and an 8.
 So, we simply want to compute $14+41+28+82$.
 Adding the first two and the last two in pairs gives $55 + 110$, which is easily computed to be $\boxed{165}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes sum :: int
assumes h0 : "sum = (\<Sum>x\<in>{(10*a + b)| a b. a \<in> {1..9} & b \<in> {0..9} & (a = 4 * b | b = 4 * a)}. x)"
shows  "sum = 165"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Calculate the sum of all two-digit numbers where either the tens digit is four times the units digit or the units digit is four times the tens digit. The final answer is 165.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = ((n > 9 \<and> n < 100) \<and> (\<exists> a b. n = 10 * a + b \<and> (a = 4 * b \<or> b = 4 * a)))"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. f n \<longrightarrow> n \<le> 165"
shows  "sum_list (filter f [0..<165]) = 165"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all the positive two-digit integers where one of the digits is four times the other? The final Answer is 165
 ### Proof
 The only such possible two-digit integers will be composed with either a 1 and a 4 or a 2 and an 8.
 So, we simply want to compute $14+41+28+82$.
 Adding the first two and the last two in pairs gives $55 + 110$, which is easily computed to be $\boxed{165}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = ((n > 9 \<and> n < 100) \<and> (\<exists> a b. n = 10 * a + b \<and> (a = 4 * b \<or> b = 4 * a)))"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. f n \<longrightarrow> n \<le> 165"
shows  "sum_list (filter f [0..<165]) = 165"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Consider a function $f$ that takes an integer $n$ and returns true if $n$ is a two-digit number and there exist integers $a$ and $b$ such that $n = 10a + b$ and either $a = 4b$ or $b = 4a$. Furthermore, if $f(n)$ is true, then $n \leq 165$. Find the sum of all integers less than 165 for which $f$ returns true. The final Answer is 165.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b. (a < 10 \<and> b < 10) \<longrightarrow> (a = 4 * b \<or> b = 4 * a)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> i. if (\<exists> a b. i = 10 * a + b \<and> (a = 4 * b \<or> b = 4 * a)) then i else 0) {10..99} = 165"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all the positive two-digit integers where one of the digits is four times the other? The final Answer is 165
 ### Proof
 The only such possible two-digit integers will be composed with either a 1 and a 4 or a 2 and an 8.
 So, we simply want to compute $14+41+28+82$.
 Adding the first two and the last two in pairs gives $55 + 110$, which is easily computed to be $\boxed{165}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b. (a < 10 \<and> b < 10) \<longrightarrow> (a = 4 * b \<or> b = 4 * a)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> i. if (\<exists> a b. i = 10 * a + b \<and> (a = 4 * b \<or> b = 4 * a)) then i else 0) {10..99} = 165"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the sum of all two-digit numbers such that either the tens digit is four times the units digit or the units digit is four times the tens digit. The final answer is 165.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sum :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sum n = (if n \<ge> 10 \<and> n \<le> 99 \<and> (n div 10 = 4 * (n mod 10) \<or> n mod 10 = 4 * (n div 10)) then n else 0)"
shows  "(\<Sum>n\<le>99. sum n) = 165"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all the positive two-digit integers where one of the digits is four times the other? The final Answer is 165
 ### Proof
 The only such possible two-digit integers will be composed with either a 1 and a 4 or a 2 and an 8.
 So, we simply want to compute $14+41+28+82$.
 Adding the first two and the last two in pairs gives $55 + 110$, which is easily computed to be $\boxed{165}$.
 *)

shows  "(\<Sum>n\<le>99. sum n) = 165"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Calculate the sum of all two-digit natural numbers for which either the tens digit is four times the units digit or the units digit is four times the tens digit. The final answer is 165.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "f = (\<lambda>n. if \<exists>a b. n = a * 10 + b \<and> a < 10 \<and> b < 10 \<and> (a = 4 * b \<or> b = 4 * a) then n else 0)"
shows  "sum f {i. i \<ge> 10 \<and> i \<le> 99} = 165"
a_7.formal solution:

 Adding the first two and the last two in pairs gives $55 + 110$, which is easily computed to be $\boxed{165}$.
 *)

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a \<in> {1..9}"
and h1 : "b \<in> {0..9}"
and h2 : "(a = 4*b \<or> b = 4*a) \<and> a \<noteq> b"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> i. if (i div 10 = a \<and> i mod 10 = b) \<or> (i div 10 = b \<and> i mod 10 = a) then i else 0) {10..99} = 165"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all the positive two-digit integers where one of the digits is four times the other? The final Answer is 165
 ### Proof
 The only such possible two-digit integers will be composed with either a 1 and a 4 or a 2 and an 8.
 So, we simply want to compute $14+41+28+82$.
 Adding the first two and the last two in pairs gives $55 + 110$, which is easily computed to be $\boxed{165}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a \<in> {1..9}"
and h1 : "b \<in> {0..9}"
and h2 : "(a = 4*b \<or> b = 4*a) \<and> a \<noteq> b"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> i. if (i div 10 = a \<and> i mod 10 = b) \<or> (i div 10 = b \<and> i mod 10 = a) then i else 0) {10..99} = 165"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Consider all two-digit numbers that have digits from 1 to 9 for the tens place and digits from 0 to 9 for the ones place. Among these numbers, find those where one digit is four times the other, and the two digits are not the same. Sum up all such numbers. The total sum is 165.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sum_4x :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n \<le> 99 \<and> (n div 10 = 4 * (n mod 10) \<or> (n mod 10) = 4 * (n div 10)) \<longrightarrow> sum_4x n = n"
shows  "(\<Sum> n = 10..99. sum_4x n) = 165"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all the positive two-digit integers where one of the digits is four times the other? The final Answer is 165
 ### Proof
 The only such possible two-digit integers will be composed with either a 1 and a 4 or a 2 and an 8.
 So, we simply want to compute $14+41+28+82$.
 Adding the first two and the last two in pairs gives $55 + 110$, which is easily computed to be $\boxed{165}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes sum_4x :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n \<le> 99 \<and> (n div 10 = 4 * (n mod 10) \<or> (n mod 10) = 4 * (n div 10)) \<longrightarrow> sum_4x n = n"
shows  "(\<Sum> n = 10..99. sum_4x n) = 165"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the sum of all two-digit numbers such that either the tens digit is four times the units digit or the units digit is four times the tens digit. The final answer is 165.
